text: Right, well, good morning and welcome everybody. Welcome to today's Strategic Planning and Policy Committee meeting. Nice to be here and to see you all. I see we've got media in the room and obviously we're streaming online. Just reminders that that is the case.  So let's kick off with our agenda then, shall we? First matter of the day is our usual apologies. I understand we have apologies from Mayor Jim and we have Councillors Barnes and Gordon zooming in and obviously Kirsty Downey as well. So welcome to you guys up there on the screen.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: Thank you, my apologies for not being there in person, Madam Chair.
speaker: rogergordon

text: Thank you, Roger. So I'm happy to move that we accept the apology from Jim and seconded by Phillip. All those in favour say aye. Aye. Against? Carried. Excellent. Next one then is a disclosure of members' interests. Have we got any conflicts of interest for anybody this morning in respect of our items? Nope. Nothing for noting. Excellent. Late items, I'm not aware of there being any.  Nope, there are none, and therefore we need somebody to confirm the order of our meeting for us. Andrew's happy to move that. Mike's gonna second that. All those in favour say aye. Aye. Against. Carried. Moving on then to the confirmation of the minutes of our meeting in June. These appear on page eight of our agenda. So I'll just flick through the pages and give me a holler if there's anything you wish to address. Pages eight and nine, 10 and 11,  And 12. minutes there.  We're fine, and everybody's quite, you're happy with that, Lou? Thank you very much, Lee. Obviously, can't be Clare or Hazel, so, and Bruce will second that. All those in favour, say aye. Aye. Against? Carried. And elastic. Moving on then to our first substantive item on our agenda this morning. It is the Waipa District Council Community Recovery Fund proposed public funding round. Good morning, Sally. Nice to see you.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: Kia ora katoa. As discussed and requested at your last meeting, today's report provides an outline for a public funding round from the Waipa District Council Community Recovery Fund, along with revised criteria and a draft application form. This funding round has been developed to allow decision making and allocation of funding at the September 2022 committee meeting. So this is trying to get this in before the end of this training.  The criteria has been based on feedback that you have provided over the last 10 months with what I think we've previously talked about as being an ever-changing COVID-19 environment. It is proposed all of the criteria is to be met within the applications and some key points of the criteria has been a local WIPA activity or project promoting response to or recovery from the impacts of COVID-19.  We've also included businesses and not just community groups based on our discussions. Evidence of connection of the activity project to the full well-beings. So this is once again to align with opening up to business opportunities and we will add an explanation around the full well-beings within the information to help applicants.  Applications cannot be retrospective and must not have received funding for the similar activity or project from council. So the draft application form included in Appendix 2 is an updated version of the first form we used, and this is being updated to connect with the criteria that's been set to show those connections through the application.  The amount for this funding round I'm proposing has been at $80,000. So this is based on discussions had at the last meeting and allows for another funding opportunity in the new year as we're aware COVID-19 continues to be within our community and we have got new variants coming into the country as well. So obviously still dealing with COVID.  As part of the costs, I'm also suggesting some funding of up to 5,000 to help support advertising of this funding round to get that awareness out there as well as developing some collateral as required. So based on your discussions today, really happy to receive any feedback and we can update this to enable it to go out to the community in a week or so to allow us to do that update there. So really open to any questions.  Thanks Sally.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: Claire, I think, and then Roger and Mike.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: Thanks Sally. I wasn't involved in the workshop that discussed this previously, but I feel it is really important that the purpose of the first criteria, it seems to cover initiatives that would be directed at, you know, COVID-19 sort of  responses, but I was also wanting to see where an organisation is suffering effects themselves, you know, with their sustainability, I guess. And that doesn't seem to be covered under that first point. And the second thing I'd like to query is the use of this fund to support advertising of it.  because I don't wanna see the quantum reduced for something which I feel is business as usual for council and that surely there's an existing budget that could be drawn on. So those are my two main points.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: So through the chair, in terms of adding, so in sustainability, we have identified an item number three, it talks about resilience to the impacts. So instead of being one of responding, it's responding to community business resilience. So that long term view is covered in number three.  Were you thinking, Councillor Clare, around it being operational cost? Is that where your operational view from that perspective? So maybe we add that into that as well. That point three, I did not pick up that the intent was to support an organisation whose normal funding streams are actually dried up or access to grants.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: That's what I'm hearing from community groups that  They're either not able to fundraise or, you know, do the things that they normally were able to to support themselves and that the grants also that they might be relying on have certainly reduced. Yeah. So I'd be keen to see something about these operational costs have suffered or yeah.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: No problem. So you can add that and maybe it's activity project or operational impact could be added to that first one.  And in terms of the discussions that happened at the last meeting, we were asked to bring back what the cost could be to do this. So obviously, up to the direction of the committee, if you would like us to utilize the fund for some of the collateral building, et cetera, cost around doing this funding or whether or not I need to find it elsewhere. It's only a small amount that we're suggesting, so it's not a huge budget there.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: You comfortable with the inclusion of that word, Clare? Excellent, cool, thank you. Roger, then Mike.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: Yeah, thanks, Madam Chair. And my question was very much along the same lines as Clare. And really, we had discussed a couple of weeks ago an organisational that had, through the impacts of COVID, had sustainability challenges.  And you've said that in terms of operational costs, this may well be now included, which is great. However, the circumstance that we looked at was really retrospective.  and this set of criteria states that the application may not be retrospective. Is there any way in which such a retrospective performance, such as the one that we previously discovered, could be included within these criteria?
speaker: rogergordon

text: Good point, Roger. Sally.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: So back through the chair, thank you for raising that. And the retrospective aspect has always been included within the fund itself. So very much up to take direction from the committee on whether or not you would like retrospective activities to be considered or not. So we'll take your direction on that.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: I would certainly support that because really a lot of these organizations do try  extremely hard and they put their minds and they get stressed out about the way that the organization is going. And it's not until they get to the point where they can't seem to go any further that they realize that they've got to shout and ask for help. This is the kind of help that they would ask for. So I don't know what the wording, I can't suggest the wording, but I personally would like to see some form of respectivity being included in this.  Anybody suggest any wording?
speaker: rogergordon

text: Liz and then Clare have a comment to make on that.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: Yeah, just on that, Roger, a lot of fundraising, well, I guess groups don't go down this road for very good reason. Retrospective funding can be very, very tricky.  Any groups that are in the situation that you've outlined, I think, Roger, will have ongoing operational costs, or they'll certainly have a, I think, something that they can come to the council for to help, you know, fit this criteria. So if there's a group that is right on the cusp, as you suggested, you know, we could certainly, I think we should certainly look at it, but retrospective funding can be, I think it's dangerous, and I'd be really concerned if we sort of went down that route.  The other point I was just going to make, sorry Sally, is that in terms of the ability to get this fund recognised and certainly promoted out there in our communities, we have existing organisations that can do that for us. The local iSites, the Citizens Advice Bureaus, there's lots of organisations that have databases that can get to all of these clubs and organisations anyway, so  I'd like to think that we can do that without having to kind of take money from the fund, you know, as Claire was saying. So I think our community groups have tentacles already into other community groups as well.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: Just commenting on that, a lot of other groups are on social media, so we can use the social media to get the message out. I was going to comment on the retrospective aspect.
speaker: rogergordon

text: So I would imagine that it could be handled by saying that  if there was an operational deficit showing up in the current financial year, because I think that's where, so it's sort of not quite retrospective, but it's an organisation that's operating and they can say, look, our normal operating expenses are say $50,000 and we normally get grants to cover that. We've missed out on $30,000 worth of grants and we can forecast  you know, that deficit. And so it's in the current financial year. So it's not like they've sort of incurred, like they've bought something and then, oh, we don't have the money to pay for it. But it's, I don't know, how do people feel about that? I think Andrew's probably got some good ideas. Yeah. I mean, I think as long as it's contained within the current financial year or something, you hopefully are giving some safeguards about a lot of  other retrospective expenses that you don't want to have to fund. Thanks, Clare.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: Graham, I believe. Thank you. I couldn't support the retrospective at all. We had several over the times I've been in the community board, we've had several times when people have come in and wanted retrospective and we've been very, very hard nosed about that.  It can lead to a situation where somebody hives off with what they perceive as a good idea. They get into a little bit of strife. Oh, we'll go back to the board and pick that up. No, you must be up front before you start so the board's got a complete picture of what's going on and to allow those funds to be allocated. And then there's no trickiness in the whole Bloomin' thing where all and something can fall behind something and then go back for a retrospective claim. That's how I would see it.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: And Graham, you don't think that time  capturing it to the current financial year would be of any benefit, you're quite clear around there should be no retrospective.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: I'm clear on that. What we found was over the years, as the funding applications got more known about, for want of a better word, then people got the idea of coming back at one time or a second time, but they complied. And we soon got rid of those ones. I don't mean that in a bad way, but we soon sorted the ones that felt they could come back for retrospective funding at some stage here.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: Mike, and then Lou.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: Yeah, thank you, through the chair. A couple of things, the $5,000, I struggle with it a little bit, but some ideas have already been expressed. So I was just going to ask, was there any detail around what that $5,000 may be spent on? But hopefully we can kick that to touch, or at least most of it.  The retrospective thing, I think I pretty much agree with Graham. I mean, it's difficult retrospective of Ops project. It starts getting really messy. Yeah, yeah, so yeah, it's trouble to support anything retrospective. I think you just gotta manage your budgets and then there's just too much risk, exactly what Graham said, of actually having a crack at something, not getting it.  or not panning out and then coming back, hoping you're going to get some money from here and hope it's not a great strategy, so.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: OK, so I think it's anybody else have any particularly help strong held views on the issue of retrospective? No? OK.  Lou, did you want to add something?
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: I'll just add the fact that very much like the councillor did, it's the fact that I do agree that there is a funding deficit. If you go back into retrospective, you actually open up a very, very large area, which is very difficult to actually administer. I would say one thing that as involved with a little bit of funding and actually a lot of volunteer groups, there is huge deficits out there at the moment, right across the spectrum.  And we're seeing normal sponsorship and community donations drawing up right across the spectrum. At junior sport, particularly, this is starting to impact. So we will see a large amount of applications, I think, from these sort of organisations. And just remember that this fund is limited and it's time limited as well as limited in size. So I think we've got to really be a bit careful that we just don't open up, we just don't have an unlimited box.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: Thanks, Lou. Claire.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: Yeah, I just like this. I respect what people have said about retrospective funding. I just feel that in this situation, we may see some organisations actually go under. And I wouldn't like to see that because we're wanting to be very careful about retrospective funding and stuff like that. But I mean, it's clear in the criteria what's being looked for and perhaps  It can be worked so that they can demonstrate that whatever it is that they're seeking support for is a future. Yeah, the future requirement. Yeah, I just don't want to see clubs failing. Yeah, nobody does, Clare.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: I just have one quick. Hold on a minute, Roger, you can follow me. Just just a quick point of clarification. Were we saying that there needed to be  the projects or activities need to have a connection with at least two of the four? Yeah, my concern is that I think it should be one.  because I feel like two is quite a lot to cover off. And I mean, there could be a really strong and application with great merit that only covers one. And by virtue of the criteria, it's no longer eligible. And I sort of, my sense is that's getting narrowing down the eligibility so much so that a lot of really meritorious applicants would be knocked out.  So I would, I mean, I don't know how the rest of the team feel, but I think two is just a bar too high. I'm happy with just the one and obviously a better description of what the well-beings are, because we know what that is.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: No, I would agree with you, Susan. Absolutely. I think that makes a lot of sense. The other thing, too, I was going to mention was that point number six in the application criteria. Can we pop in the applications must be supported by a copy of the applicants?  all the current bank statements or their most, you know, because sometimes clubs have more than one bank statement or bank account. And I just would like to make sure we have a copy, most current copy of all of them, savings accounts in particular.

text: Yeah. Good clarification. Yeah. Great. Thanks for that, Roger. And then Mike.

text: Yeah, thanks, Madam Chair. Yeah, I mean, having been a previous member with Graeme and Mike on the community board and fully aware of some of the techniques some organisations may have used in the past, I'd just like to bring us back to the fact that this is not a perpetual fund or it's not going to be  repeated forever. It's a specific purpose. It's really defined resilience to the impacts of COVID. And I think all applications will be reviewed in light of that. So again, like Claire, I'd just like to make sure that those organizations that have a  an operational stress on them currently, do feel that they can apply to this fund.
speaker: rogergordon

text: Yeah, thanks, Roger. text: They don't really tell you about that year so much and what's planned and all the rest of it. And it just gives you a real state of play of actually equity and how much money really there is kicking about. Yeah.

text: I'd support a balance sheet, Mike.  Definitely, yeah.

text: Great idea, Mike. Thank you, Roger. Yes, Sally.

text: Just on number six, this is what really I think we're looking for, is last year's financial accounts. Then you get a picture of their term deposits and everything.  And we've found that invaluable on the community board, really, really invaluable.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: Thank you. I'd like to reflect exactly what Councillor Weber just said, because I work in a charity and distribute money from a gaming trust. And in actual fact, we find that this is actual.  fact, any charity has to register and have a balance sheet. And I do think I go along with Mo over there or Councillor Pettit with the fact that we need that. It gives us a broader picture. Just remembering that this fund is, as I said originally, quite limited and quite time constrained. So we can't go digging into details. I just wanted to add one thing while I'm speaking. We might get flooded with applications.  And this is quite a possibility. And would we actually like to record those? Because we are facing, I think, quite a large crisis here. And we saw this with our last discretionary fund through the community board. We had far more applicants than we had funds by a large degree. And I was just wondering whether we actually utilize this as stating that we might have to get some funding from central government or some way to actually recover this or actually help with this.  but we need the figures first to be able to go out and do it. So I just thought it was a thought to leave aside. Thanks, Lee.

text: Alright, moving on then in our agenda to the district plan work program of July 2022. Joe, good morning. Kia ora, take a seat.  Nice to see you in person.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: Oh my, it's good. It's good to be here. It's quite weird to be at a meeting in person after all this time. It's quite exciting.  I will keep the district plan update short. As you can see, we are really busy. The priority one is the housing intensification plan change, the mandatory plan change from central government. We go out next week to do our pre-notification consultation with iwi and other statutory bodies. We're looking forward to feedback.  we almost have all of our infrastructure review reports in. We are drafting madly. So I've had extra resource from the consents team. I've been utilizing the project planner, which has been awesome. So we're on track to start notification of the plan change on the week starting the 15th.  of August, so it has to be notified on the 20th of August, which is a Saturday. We'll be notifying in the Waikato Times jointly with Waikato District on the 19th, and it will go up on our website. Earlier that week, we will go into the two Cambridge newspapers and the Te Aumutu newspaper, and we will start doing letter drops to ratepayers that week as well.  There will be a council workshop on recommendations that have come out of the technical reports that we've had done. And I will be bringing to the next ESPNP committee the plan change as a whole for comment and for approval to notify. So we're feeling on track, just feels like it's been a very tight schedule.  and long process. Other plan changes are progressing. You will have Nita from Beka after me talking about plan change 17, how to structure plans and plan change 19, Carter Flat, Commercial Zone, Papakāinga is progressing nicely. Stage one has been contracted out to Future Consultancy Group and he's currently scoping it up for us.  We have had a number of private plan change inquiries, but at this stage they are just inquiries. And the only other aspect, because it's the next item on the agenda, is draft plan change 21. We are looking  to defer the notification of that until early next year to align with Hamilton City, who will be notifying early next year as well, but also to give a little bit of breathing space between plan change 26 being notified and then we can start on PC 21. And the last update is we get a graduate policy planner starting on Monday. Very exciting.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: Excellent. Very exciting. Wonderful. Thank you, Jo. Very busy times. Can I just say something? Is there any appetite to call plan changes anything different than the numbers? I mean, I know that from a technical sense, it makes sense, but in terms of discussions around this table and actually talking to our communities, talking numbers just is not particularly helpful.  I mean, if we use some other descriptor, it might actually have a greater meaning. I mean, I sit there and I assume, being a very average person, that half of the people that you talk to won't understand what you're saying. So it's just a conversation starter, really, for 10. Perhaps it's something we could look at going forward, because it has more meaning if a draft plan change has a descriptor rather than a number. And I understand the technical sense or need for it, but in terms of conversations beyond  our offices, I think it would be really helpful.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: I would I would completely agree with that, Susan, and in the conversation with the Chamber of Commerce yesterday, you know, because there are so many plan changes and we're all getting a bit confused in our numbers, actually, so a better descriptor would be helpful.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: I feel a little bit like a one armed bandit. My eyes kind of go around in my head and I'm trying to work out, you know, what what plan change it is. So just, yeah, putting it out there. Yeah. Seems to have a bit of positivity around the table. Mike?
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: Yeah, through the chair, what about keeping the numbers and then just bracketing the actual descriptor? You know, then the numbers get lost to the people who are not interested in them.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: What we have been trialling when we've been talking to people is using the descriptor first. Excellent, yeah. So for Plan Change 26,  I've been talking to people about the residential zone intensification, the housing intensification plan change. So we've been trialling, just flipping it. Yeah, excellent. More than happy to keep doing that. And it will also give us the ability to think about the use of better descriptors.

text: Excellent. Yeah. And sort of simple, plain English that moves away from local government jingoisms.

text: I'm trying to keep all the plan changes straight in my head. So this report builds on the brief discussion I had in the work programme update. I took a change request to the staff growth programme steering group to request that we defer the notification of plan change 21 until early next year.  Part of the reasoning for that was the time commitment required for the residential zone intensification plan change. That's been all consuming for a number of months. And the second reason was Hamilton City had deferred the notification of those. And we just feel because we are doing  those two plan changes would be good to go out at the same time and try and achieve consistency across the two councils. The other intent of this report is just to update you on the technical reports that we've had commissioned both for plan change 26, the housing intensification and plan change 21. So we have  received our character and heritage review back, and that recommends the retention of character clusters, addition of some heritage sites, houses into the heritage register, introduction of character streets,  Rather than having a blanket just a special character area like we currently have so getting quite specific of where the character areas clusters are and that's a requirement of the legislation that we have to do site by site analysis.  We've also had an excellent report back on green infrastructure and open spaces. And that will enable us to put some qualifying measures down to protect open spaces, parks and reserves and our green infrastructure throughout Cambridge, Kihiki and Te Ara Mutu.  We've had stormwater and transportation back, and I'm about to dive into those today to see what their recommendations are. And I think we're waiting on water, the water review to come back, and then Becca is doing a summary report of all our infrastructure reports, just so we've got the main points in one document. So further details on our technical reports will be provided at the council meeting later on.  this month and what I'm aiming to do is just under each section just have the main recommendations and also to indicate yes we've carried those through into PC26, no we haven't and this is why we haven't. Some recommendations are out of scope, some are awesome and they are going to help us moving forward to keep our amenity and our character in the Waipā district.

text: Yes, thank you, Madam Chair.  Now, as you're aware, and Kirsty and David is aware, I went through the document in considerable detail. And I had a fair raft of questions. But  In these questions, I am really specifically addressing Cambridge. My apologies to Tiawamutu and other councillors, but I've done it in regard to that consideration. So the first question is that in page 19, the principles  of the document state that the intention is to implement the strategy through the RPS and the district plan. And then if you flick on to page 96, it clearly identifies that the Cambridge and TA target densities for defined intensification areas and greenfield developments. And they're quite considerably  higher than what we currently have in our district plan. And then on page 112, matters for inclusion  in the Waikato RPS change, it states that they will be. So there's no doubt that those intensification target densities are going to be included in the regional policy statement.  Now, my challenge and my question of David is once they're included in the regional policy statement, in terms of the hierarchy, that means that that is above our district plan so that when we have a plan change, it's like this national policy statement of higher densities, we can't actually object against it.  If they're in the RPS, then our local opportunity to vary that is removed. So we must agree to those higher levels of density. Now, I'm taking it that that will apply  to those areas in our growth cells that are currently not covered by development agreement or under construction now. So it'll be all of those newer outlying areas. Am I correct in that assumption?
speaker: rogergordon

text: Through you Madam Chair, Councillor Gordon, that's a good question. I think just going back to where you started, just to note, future proof itself, the strategy document is non-statutory. So it's not a document that has enforcement weight.  itself. But as you mentioned, the idea is that key elements such as the density targets get incorporated into an update to the regional policy statement, which as you correctly state,  is a statutory document that we have to give effect to. So yes, in the course of time, it does manifest in something we do have to give effect to. But as I started by saying,  The whole thing's been overtaken by government legislation introduced at the end of last year. So the amendment to the RMA that broadened the medium density residential standards actually supersedes this. And one of Joe Cook-Monroe's plan changes, plan change 26,  is about enabling greater housing density, and that's to give effect to the legislation. So in terms of the tier, national legislation will trump the RPS. So in fact, anything we're doing now, we have to kind of wait and see what  comes out from the plan change process that is giving effect to the amendment to the RMA. I don't know if that makes sense. Yeah, it does make sense.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: But I've got a vision that, you know, if these were to go through, and if the national policy statements changes that will occur in the future, we're going to finish up with a character town. And then we're going to have a whole lot of suburbs around the town, which are going to be considerably higher density.  And I've seen that overseas and that don't work.
speaker: rogergordon

text: Yeah. And again, I think you you raise some valid concerns and we're aware of them. So that is one of the concerns. And we've got to go through our plan change process. One of the things Joe mentioned, what we're looking at is what are our qualifying matters that we can take into account to mitigate a kind of blanket application of those medium density standards. But we all know in the real world,  built environment doesn't change quickly. You can't just transform the landscape in an existing town into something else. And I guess you can take a little bit of comfort in this not being a binding document, but it would be nice if it was a little more accurate in that respect. And Liz, yeah, I agree with your comments, absolutely.
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: Can you turn your microphone on, please? My apologies.
speaker: rogergordon

text: My apologies. I think we've probably discussed this fairly comprehensively. So if we just turn to page 46 of our report, which has the two recommendations appearing there, to receive David's report and to approve the updated 2022 future proof strategy attached to that report. You're happy to move, Graham? Anybody's to second? Liz will second for me. All those in favour say aye. Aye. Against?
speaker: waipadistrictcouncil

text: Yes, I'd like to vote against it. I just don't- Roger, would you like it recorded? I would, I just don't think it serves Cambridge well. It will become a regional policy statement and that concerns me.
speaker: rogergordon

text: Okay, Roger's the only person who wishes to record against? Excellent, carried. Thank you, thank you, David. Thank you for your hard work and thank you, Kirsty. Thank you. So we now have a resolution to exclude the public.  I'm happy to move from the chair and Mike will second for me. All those in favour say aye.
